awd_titl_txt: Lessons Learned: Navigating a Presidential Election During a Pandemic
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2020 election has the potential to introduce challenges not only for voters searching for accurate information on candidates and voting procedures, but also for officials, poll workers, and cybersecurity experts working to administer and protect the electoral process. This award supports a workshop bringing together experts from a range of relevant fields to discuss lessons learned from the 2020 election. The workshop will explore how our country can continually improve our electoral process to be resilient in the most trying of times while simultaneously advancing basic scientific research on all aspects of the voting process. By sparking long-term collaboration across scholars and practitioners that rarely engage with one another, the workshop will help generate new research ideas and partnerships that will chart the course for future election research. 

The myriad challenges posed by 2020 elections provide a strong opportunity for interdisciplinary research (e.g., voter behavior at the intersection of political science, sociology, psychology, and information science; voting access at the intersection of election law, data science, and cybersecurity). However, traditional professional society meetings rarely enable the interdisciplinary dialogue necessary to develop a comprehensive understanding of the successes and shortcomings of the 2020 election. The workshop brings together scholars from across disciplines, including law, political science, computer science, data science, and mathematics. The output from the workshop will be a widely-disseminated document that lays out the new or updated research problems and ideas that could lead to a potential NSF DCL to solicit new proposals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The 2020 election introduced challenges not only for voters searching for accurate information on candidates and voting procedures, but also for officials, poll workers, and cybersecurity experts working to administer and protect the electoral process. The breadth of these challenges impacted every stage of voting and intersected with the expertise of scholars from across disciplines. The workshop brought together scholars from across disciplines, including law, political science, computer science, data science, and mathematics. By bringing together experts from a range of relevant fields to discuss lessons learned from the 2020 election, the workshop explored how our country can continually improve our electoral process to be resilient in the most trying of times while simultaneously advancing basic scientific research on all aspects of the voting process. The workshop was organized around three key thematic areas, each of which will consist of two sessions: election infrastructure, information ecosystems, and voting. A final session drew out the potential points of intersection between these three areas. In each session, special attention was paid to the differential effects by demographic groups, such as by race, gender, age, disability, and geography. By sparking collaboration and dialogue across scholars and practitioners that rarely engage with one another, the workshop helped generate new research ideas and partnerships that will chart the course for future election research. After the conference, a whitepaper synthesized the key themes and insights. 


A theme that emerged during the workshop was the quality of information that people were exposed to impacted democratic society generally and election administration specifically. Due to the public health advisories that were still in effect during early 2021, this initial workshop occurred online. As a result, the initial grant was able to support two additional conferences that focused specifically on the relationship between the digital information environment and politics. The conferences brought together leading scholars from around the globe to present new research. One of the main objectives of the conference was to enable researchers to receive feedback on in-progress projects. To that end, projects were presented and feedback was given during the conference itself. Beyond the conference itself, the research projects presented have led and will lead to papers that are published in academic journals. In addition to disseminating and facilitating feedback on new projects, the conference enabled time for networking and discussing new lines of research.
